poem:
**Sober Curious**

In the amber light of evening,  
half-heard laughter spills like cider  
from beer gardens brimmed with spring.  
Heads turned, shoulders brushed, yet some  
sip quiet clarity, soft edges of sobriety—  
sharp as frost on martini glass rims—  
seeking self in the whisper of abstinence,  
finding value in silence, not spirits.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I am sober curious – but a little alcohol is still valuable to me | Emma Beddington The sun is out, the football is on, beer gardens are packed and sunset-pink shots of condensation-frosted palomas (the new negroni) are plastered across Instagram, but I bet someone in your life has given up drinking. Maybe more than one person. I know lots (if you count parasocial “knowing”, and I don’t get out much, so I do).". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
